What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We've learned a lot regarding the calculation of upper and lower bounds of the minimax risk under different statistical models. For example, LASSO regression, graphical estimation, frequentist Bayesian investigation, EM algorithm, etc.

Topics in decision theory (estimation and risk lower bound arguments, high-dimensional estimation like LASSO, evaluation of Bayesian procedures, algorithms like spectral clustering and EM, Stochastic Block Model and community detection, etc.)

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The workload is light, you can totally enjoy the course materials without worrying too much about the homework. On the other hand, the amount of knowledge you took away always highly dependent on homework and exams. This course provides you a lot of fascinating results, thoughts and methods of theoretical statistics, but how much you actually got depended on how much time contribution you would like to have for it.

This is a great course for learning a lot of theoretical results in statistics in a digestible way. Professor Zhou uses simple examples to introduce and prove results, which make them much easier to understand than other textbooks/papers. His lectures are also paced well, and he pauses often to make sure everyone understands the material. The workload is also very reasonable (we had 6 homework assignments that were 1 question each and could be submitted up until the end of the semester). The homework helped us solidify our understanding from the lecture and gave us practice with certain calculations.

As a student not as rehearsed in theoretical statistics I liked the forgiving pace of the lecture and how the professor stops and makes sure that every one of his students understands what is happening before moving forward.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had live lectures and recordings and handwritten notes uploaded to canvas, and weakly held professor's office hour, so it is easy for us to get access to course materials or help.
The virtual format over zoom with a (tablet) whiteboard worked well for the course.
Recorded lecture and lecture notes were very helpful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoy taking Harry's course, hope you all enjoy it too.
Yes, I'd recommend it to anyone who took S&DS 410 and is interested in more of those kinds of results.

Yes! Harry is an excellent lecturer who also cares for his students, often stopping lecture to ask students individually if they have questions. He genuinely cares that his students are engaged and learning and can take something out of this class for future work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We have a very interactive live lecture. Professor Zhou have had a lot of communication with us during lecture to make sure we have followed his pace.
